title: Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)
scope: ** Diagnostic workup, acute attack management, and long-term disease-modifying therapy for NMOSD. Covers AQP4-IgG seropositive and seronegative NMOSD, acute optic neuritis, longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM), area postrema syndrome, acute brainstem syndrome, symptomatic narcolepsy, and acute cerebral syndrome. Includes relapse treatment, attack prevention, and supportive care. For isolated optic neuritis without NMOSD features, see "Optic Neuritis" template. For MS, see "MS - New Diagnosis" and "MS - Chronic Management" templates. For MOG antibody disease (MOGAD), a distinct entity, specific MOGAD guidance is noted where management differs.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (neuroimmunology/MS specialist) for NMOSD diagnosis confirmation and long-term disease management
Neuro-ophthalmology for visual acuity assessment, OCT monitoring, and visual rehabilitation
Ophthalmology for acute optic neuritis evaluation and fundoscopic examination
Urology for neurogenic bladder management including urodynamics and catheterization planning
Physical therapy for mobility assessment, gait training, and fall prevention given myelopathy-related weakness
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, upper extremity rehabilitation, and energy conservation strategies
Pain management for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to first-line agents
Social work for disability resources, insurance navigation for specialty biologics, and psychological support
Infectious disease for pre-immunosuppression screening and management of infections on immunotherapy
Hematology/apheresis service for PLEX coordination and catheter placement
Rehabilitation medicine for comprehensive inpatient rehab program coordination following severe relapse
Rheumatology if concurrent autoimmune disease (SLE, Sjogren, myasthenia) requiring co-management

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for new or worsening vision loss, numbness/weakness, urinary retention, or intractable vomiting (may indicate relapse requiring urgent treatment)
NMOSD is a lifelong condition requiring continuous preventive therapy -- stopping treatment significantly increases relapse risk and disability
Do NOT use MS-specific medications (interferons, fingolimod, natalizumab) as these may worsen NMOSD
Report any fever, cough, or signs of infection immediately while on immunotherapy (infection risk is increased)
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive therapy; inform all physicians of immunosuppression status
Keep all infusion appointments; missed doses increase relapse risk
Pregnancy must be discussed with neurology BEFORE conception as most NMOSD treatments are teratogenic; planned pregnancy requires treatment coordination
Carry medical alert identification indicating NMOSD diagnosis and immunosuppressive medications
Report new headache, neck stiffness, or fever urgently if on eculizumab/ravulizumab (risk of meningococcal infection)
Adequate hydration and regular exercise as tolerated to support rehabilitation and overall health
Vision changes should be reported promptly -- early relapse treatment preserves vision

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation to reduce inflammatory burden and improve vascular health
Vitamin D supplementation (2000-4000 IU daily) with level monitoring (target >40 ng/mL) given association between low vitamin D and autoimmune disease activity
Vaccination review: update all non-live vaccines before starting immunotherapy; annual influenza and pneumococcal vaccination
Meningococcal vaccination (ACWY + serogroup B) REQUIRED before eculizumab/ravulizumab; maintain boosters per schedule
Stress management and adequate sleep to reduce relapse triggers
Home safety evaluation for fall prevention given myelopathy-related gait impairment
Bone health: calcium 1000-1200 mg/day + vitamin D if on chronic steroids; DEXA if steroids >3 months
Contraception counseling: effective contraception required during most NMOSD treatments due to teratogenicity

differential.features: Relapsing-remitting course; Dawson fingers on MRI; periventricular/juxtacortical/infratentorial lesions; short cord lesions (<3 segments); positive OCBs in ~85%
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine patterns; OCBs; AQP4-IgG negative; McDonald criteria

differential.features: MOG-IgG positive; often bilateral ON; conus/cauda involvement; better recovery than AQP4+ NMOSD; ADEM-like cortical lesions

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies; leptomeningeal enhancement; hilar adenopathy; elevated ACE

differential.features: Multisystem disease; skin/joint involvement; antiphospholipid antibodies
Sicca symptoms; anti-SSA/SSB; may mimic NMOSD (AQP4+ overlap reported)
Acute onset; vascular territory distribution; DWI restricted diffusion; no enhancement
differential.tests: MRI DWI; vascular risk factors; CT angiography

differential.features: Progressive; corresponding structural lesion; no inflammation
Posterior column involvement; peripheral neuropathy; macrocytic anemia
Progressive vacuolar myelopathy; immunocompromised; posterior and lateral columns
Progressive myelopathy; flow voids on MRI; older patients
differential.tests: Spinal angiography; MRI with flow voids

differential.features: Single episode; no AQP4 or MOG antibodies; no recurrence
differential.tests: Negative antibodies; follow-up MRI; clinical course

differential.features: Monophasic; post-infectious/post-vaccination; multifocal large white matter lesions; encephalopathy

differential.features: Unilateral; good recovery; no myelopathy; no recurrence
differential.tests: AQP4-IgG and MOG-IgG negative; follow-up imaging
